executive_summary: Written by Alex Kessinger (@voidfiles) and Jon Mitchell (@ablaze) in June 2013 around Google Reader's shutdown, this essay argues feed readers are the best tools for managing modern information overload, giving users control over context, pace, and place that advertising-driven websites actively deny. It covers feed architecture (sync, discovery, offline reading, triage), a five-phase information cycle, and the philosophical distinction between curation and collection. The authors warn the ecosystem faces collapse without shared back-end infrastructure and sustainable revenue models.
core_thesis: Feed readers are the optimal tool for managing modern information overload, but the ecosystem will collapse without shared sync infrastructure, sustainable revenue, and developer-publisher cooperation.
main_arguments: Feed readers return control of context, pace, and place to users, while websites impose editorial and design choices to maximize page views rather than reading efficiency.
Advertising economics drive website design against readers, stretching ever less original material into thinner, smaller chunks to multiply page views.
The Kuleshov Effect—juxtaposition of disparate feed items—allows readers to synthesize ideas not explicitly present in any single source, making folder organization cognitively powerful.

The Sopranos/Tony-centric narrative models a focused news diet (editor-driven, habitual), while The Wire/Baltimore-centric narrative models a diffuse feed-reader diet (user-curated, context-building).
Reading efficiently—measured as (amount consumed / time spent) balanced with quality of recall—is the goal; reading everything is not.
Sync is the technical cornerstone of feed readers; users must always be able to download all unread posts to manage connectivity breaks on trains, planes, and poor mobile service.
Discovery is woefully underserved in feed readers; Facebook's convergent algorithm is rarely surprising, while divergent 'tastestalking' across Del.icio.us and Pinboard offers richer discovery.
Feeds naturally decay as writers stop publishing or companies fold; users must subscribe at a slightly faster rate than feeds decay to maintain a healthy reading diet.
The triage system—organizing feeds into prioritized folders with a daily-read 'Canon' folder at the top—is the key mechanism for high-throughput reading.
The five-phase modern information cycle (discovery, consumption, processing, review, internalizing) supersedes simple consumption and locks engaged readers into deeper engagement.
Frank Chimero's distinction: collecting is propagation-focused (grows in quantity and diversity), while curating is illumination-focused (brings selected items to a point of purpose).
Jony Ive's iOS 7 transition proves hardware design constraints can inform software rigor; iOS 6's skeuomorphic linen textures exploited unconstrained software freedom to its detriment.
Feed readers need a shared sync back-end platform with multiple independent interfaces layered on top; each reader building its own infrastructure is redundant and unsustainable.
CPM rates have nowhere to go but down, users have been trained by Google Reader to not pay for feed readers, and no viable revenue model for free feed readers exists.
The 'Cambrian explosion' of individual hobbyist developers competing against VC-backed teams cannot sustain the ecosystem without a platform approach and shared infrastructure.
Deliberate sharing with commentary—not plain links or Likes—is a stronger signal and a natural extension of the processing and review phases of the information cycle.
key_evidence: Google Reader closed July 1, 2013, citing declining usage, leaving at least 3 large companies and 10+ smaller projects—including Newsblur, Feedbin, Feedly, and The Old Reader—competing for the vacated market.
Chris Wetherell, Google Reader's founder/designer, stated feed readers must be 'athletically flexible to match a wide variety of reading styles' and built the product on a flexibility premise.
Ivan Mosjoukine's expressionless face alternated by filmmaker Kuleshov with soup, a coffin, and a woman on a divan demonstrated how juxtaposition creates meaning absent from individual frames.
Facebook's black-box machine learning algorithm populates newsfeeds convergently and is 'rarely if ever going to surprise you' with genuinely new voices or topics.
Jason Kottke spent almost a decade unpaid learning to find good content online, consistently anticipating cultural discourse—cited as evidence that curation has deep, hard-won value.
Jeff Weiner at Yahoo argued companies must reduce internally competing projects to self-actualize and achieve greatness, applied here to the case for a shared feed reader platform.
Feedbin's interface shows 2,990 unread items and 47 starred items organized across canon, tech, culture, links, people, and overflow folders.

The Wire received zero Emmy awards despite critical acclaim, with David Simon admitting 'a knack for making shows that people watch only after they have been on TV'—used to argue feed readers' best days are ahead.
'Tastestalking'—following someone's taste across Social Media, Del.icio.us, and Pinboard simultaneously—gives a fuller picture of a person's thinking than any single platform alone.
A well-maintained Canon folder of highest-priority daily feeds can typically be read through in approximately 20 minutes.
Five or six individual hobbyists compete against VC-backed teams in the feed reader market, but the power law prevents all of them from winning without platform cooperation.
Feedly, recommended as the primary Google Reader replacement, faces sustainability risk because it offers a free service without an established revenue model.
Pocket is cited as the correct tool for queuing longer articles requiring concentrated focus, with the feed reader handling triage and Pocket handling deep reading as separate processes.
conclusions: Feed readers are the best current tool for information management, and their best days have not yet arrived—the ecosystem is still maturing.
A paid shared back-end sync platform—not competing independent back-ends—is the prerequisite for a sustainable feed reader market.
Tool makers and publishers must cooperate financially; without a way to pay both, the entire reading ecosystem will disappear.
Discovery must be rebuilt as a divergent, tastestalking-enabled feature to counteract the convergent narrowing of algorithmic feeds like Facebook's.
The triage system of prioritized folders—with a Canon layer for must-read daily content—is the most practical framework for high-throughput reading.
Deliberate, commentary-accompanied sharing is essential to building healthy curation networks that add value beyond propagation.
Every feed reader need not have every feature; the ecosystem must be considered as a whole, or developers risk losing sight of the user.
